In his satchel, wrapped in dragon-etched silk, the egg pulsed with a faint, rhythmic heat. He didn't go to the Physician’s chambers. Instinct, sharp and unerring, pulled him toward the King’s wing. He expected to find Arthur slumped over his desk, or perhaps staring out at the ramparts. He didn't expect the silence. Merlin pushed the door open. The hearth glowed low, a dull red. On the bed, Arthur lay on his back, arm flung across the covers. Curled into the crook of that arm, not a woman, but a small, midnight shadow, was Freya. Her tail draped over Arthur’s wrist. His fingers were loosely curled near her ears. They looked like survivors washed up on the same lonely shore. Merlin froze in the doorway, the heavy dragon egg forgotten for a moment against his hip. A lump formed in his throat, thick and painful. He had asked Arthur to look after her. He had asked Freya to look after Arthur. He hadn't realized they would have to become one single, breathing thing just to endure his departure.
